data.profileText: a Representative from Kentucky; born in what is now Nelson County, Va., in 1779; received a thorough English training; studied law; admitted to the bar and commenced practice in Stanford, Lincoln County, Ky.; judge of the circuit court of Lincoln County; member of the State house of representatives in 1811; elected as a Democratic Republican to the Thirteenth Congress (March 4, 1813-March 3, 1815); unsuccessful candidate for reelection to the Fourteenth Congress; again elected to the Sixteenth Congress to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Tunstall Quarles; reelected to the Seventeenth Congress and served from August 1, 1820, to March 3, 1823; chairman, Committee on Public Expenditures (Seventeenth Congress); died in Stanford, Ky., April 2, 1828.

note.content: Elected to fill vacancy caused by resignation of Tunstall Quarles, and took his seat November 13, 1820.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Montgomery, Thomas. The representative principle of legislation, and the force of popular instructions, examined. Washington City: Printed by Rapine and Elliot, near the capitol. 1814.
